conclusion: Four identical blocks (A, B, C, and D) are on a smooth horizontal surface; blocks B and C are connected by a light spring; a horizontal force F is applied to block B causing all blocks to accelerate together.

Since the surface is smooth, there is no friction between the blocks and the surface; the only horizontal force applied is F on block B; the spring between blocks B and C will exert a force due to its extension or compression.
According to Newton's second law, the net force on each block is equal to the mass of the block times its acceleration (F = ma).

Block D is not directly connected to the force F or the spring; it is part of the system that accelerates together; the only horizontal force that can act on block D is the static friction force between block D and block C.
For block D to accelerate with the same acceleration as the other blocks, the static friction force between block D and block C must provide the necessary force to achieve this acceleration.
The acceleration a of the system can be expressed as a = F/(4m), since the total mass of the system is 4m.
The static friction force fs acting on block D must be equal to the force required to accelerate block D: fs = ma = m * (F/(4m)) = F/4.
The magnitude of the static friction force acting on block D during the acceleration process is F/4.
